experiments.name: 001_baseline_lightgbm
experiments.notes: Baseline LightGBM model with tabular features only. Used only safe features available in both train and test sets to avoid leakage. Applied stratified 5-fold CV with class imbalance handling (scale_pos_weight=3.03). Engineered features: text lengths, temporal features, user activity ratios, and interaction terms. Overall OOF AUC: 0.6498, Mean CV AUC: 0.6729 ± 0.0293. Key findings: text length features (text_length, title_length) and temporal features (unix_timestamp_of_request) were most important. RAOP-specific activity features showed moderate importance. Model shows reasonable performance but has room for improvement with text embeddings and more sophisticated feature engineering.

web_research.query: What are winning approaches for text classification with tabular meta-data on Kaggle?
web_research.finding:
Winning Kaggle solutions for text‑classification problems that also contain tabular meta‑data usually treat the dataset as **multimodal** and combine a pretrained language model with strong gradient‑boosting tabular learners.  AutoGluon’s Tabular Predictor makes this straightforward: raw text columns are fed to a built‑in TextPredictor (a BERT‑style encoder) while numeric and categorical columns are handled by LightGBM, CatBoost or Random Forest; the framework then automatically stacks or ensembles the heterogeneous models for the final prediction ([auto.gluon.ai](https://auto.gluon.ai/0.7.0/tutorials/tabular_prediction/tabular-multimodal-text-others.html)).  

A common “two‑stage” pipeline follows the same idea. First, a transformer (e.g., BERT, Sentence‑BERT, or any LLM) converts each text field into a dense embedding. Those embeddings are then concatenated with engineered tabular features (target‑encoded categories, interaction terms, etc.) and supplied to a gradient‑boosting model

web_research.query: How do Kaggle winners handle moderate class imbalance in binary classification with 25% positive rate?
web_research.finding:
Based on the strategies shared by Kaggle competition winners and the community discussions on handling imbalanced binary targets (≈ 25 % positives), the most common workflow is:

1. **Choose a metric that reflects the minority class** – switch from plain accuracy to AUC‑ROC, PR‑AUC, or a custom loss that penalises false‑negatives/false‑positives according to the problem. This ensures the model is rewarded for correctly identifying the 25 % positive cases. ([Unbalanced data and cross‑validation | Kaggle](https://www.kaggle.com/discussions/questions-and-answers/27589))  

2. **Apply class‑weighting or cost‑sensitive learning** – many winning solutions pass the class frequencies to the algorithm (e.g., `class_weight='balanced'` in scikit‑learn, or custom loss weighting) so the minority class contributes more to the loss. ([Binary classification with strongly unbalanced classes | Stats.SE](https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/235808))  

3. **Resample the training data**

web_research.query: What text feature engineering techniques work best for social media posts and Reddit requests classification?
web_research.finding: Text classification of social‑media posts and Reddit requests benefits from a blend of classic lexical tricks and domain‑specific signals.  First, standard preprocessing—removing stopwords, applying stemming or lemmatization, and generating count‑based vectors (Bag‑of‑Words, n‑grams, TF‑IDF)—still provides a strong baseline for classical models such as Naïve Bayes or linear SVMs and helps curb the high dimensionality of short, noisy posts ([machinelearningmastery.com](https://machinelearningmastery.com/7-feature-engineering-tricks-for-text-data)).  Because social media text is littered with emojis, hashtags, user mentions, and URLs, tokenizers that treat these tokens specially (e.g., splitting or preserving hashtags, normalising URLs) improve representation quality; the RedditScore library even offers a “CrazyTokenizer” with Reddit‑ and Twitter‑specific options for this purpose ([redditscore.readthedocs.io](https://redditscore.readthedocs.io/en/master)).  Adding character‑level n‑grams

web_research.query: How do Kaggle winners handle text data leakage when training data contains edited posts with outcome information?
web_research.finding:
Kaggle winners typically neutralize text‑data leakage by first **detecting** any parts of the posts that directly reveal the target (e.g., edited “outcome” notes) and then **removing or neutralizing** that information before modeling. The common workflow is:

1. **Identify leaky signals** – Scan the text columns for strings that are highly correlated with the label (e.g., “edited because …”, “removed for …”). Kaggle notebooks on data leakage suggest using simple frequency‑or‑correlation checks to flag such columns or substrings as potential leaky predictors ([Kaggle Data‑Leakage Notebook](https://www.kaggle.com/code/dansbecker/data-leakage)).

2. **Strip outcome‑specific fragments** – Apply regex or rule‑based cleaning to delete the edited‑post annotations (e.g., anything after “[edited]”, “[removed]”, or moderator comments). This ensures the model only sees the original content.

3. **Distill the text** – When the leakage is embedded in the language itself (the text carries treatment
